title: Novak Djokovic not slowed down by fatherhood
text:
Novak Djokovic not slowed down by fatherhood 20 Oct 2015 12:46:53 
Stefan Djokovic will have no interest in the superlatives raining down on his father as he blows out the candle on his first birthday cake. 
Becoming a parent is supposed to make your work life harder but nobody told Novak Djokovic. 
In the first year of Stefan's life, Djokovic has won three grand slam titles, reached the final of a fourth, won eight other titles and lost just five matches. 
Remarkably, he has not lost before the final of any tournament in 2015 since his very first event in Doha in January. 
In an era that was supposed to be about two other players, he has emerged as one of the most dominant world number ones in tennis history. 
And the scary thing for his supposed rivals is that Djokovic seems to be getting better and better. 
After winning titles in Beijing and Shanghai without dropping a set, Djokovic declared the past fortnight the best of his career. 
He also delved into why he is so dominant right now, and the answer makes chilling reading for opponents - there is no game plan against which he does not feel superior. 
Speaking after beating Jo-Wilfried Tsonga in the final in Shanghai, Djokovic said: "I can't expect to win every single rally but, percentage?wise, I have a very good chance against anybody because I know I can adjust to anybody's game: players who are coming to the net or players who are staying back, playing flat or spin. 
"I've played so many times against so many players, over the years you develop this kind of ability to adjust. 
"But also I think specifically this year what I've done very well is I haven't waited for other players to take the initiative. I've taken the initiative first. So the quality of my first shots has been better this year than I think ever before." 
No one who watched his dismantling of an admittedly below-par Andy Murray in the semi-finals in Shanghai would disagree. Whatever tactics the Scot tried, Djokovic simply turned the rally to his advantage. 
When Stefan celebrates his second birthday next October, might Djokovic be celebrating an even better season? Don't bet against it.
